Balcomb Greene.bio: Balcomb Greene was an American artist and teacher. He and his wife, artist Gertrude Glass Greene, were heavily involved in political activism to promote mainstream acceptance of abstract art and were founding members of the American Abstract Artists organization. His early style was completely non-objective.

Archibald Evans, Jr..bio: Archibald was a student in the summer of 1949. He listed Buckminster Fuller as a reference and the reason for wanting to attend the college. On his application, he shared his plan after the summer was "to return to the Institute ofDesign. To finish 8th semester."

Erwin Bodky.bio: German-American music scholar, Erwin Bodky, was known as a child prodigy on the piano by the age of 12. His his later music education included degrees from the Preussiche Hochschule für Musik and the Scharwenka Conservatory in Berlin.

Natasha Goldowski.bio: Natasha Goldowski Renner, was a chemist and expert on the corrosion of metals and had worked on the Manhattan Project. She was a faculty member at BMC from 1947 until 1953.

Leo \"Slim\" Krikorian.bio: Leo Krikorian first heard about Black Mountain College from a girl with whom he was having a cup of coffee in Los Angeles: “She talked about Black Mountain College for maybe five, ten minutes, and I really got interested.” At the time he was studying photography at the Art Center in Los Angeles. He wrote for an application and returned it with some of his photographs. He recalled that he did not feel he had the requirements to enter conventional colleges.

Hyalie Yamins.bio: Hyalie was a student from 1936 to 1941. In 1937, Hyalie participated in Winterset: a play in three acts by Maxwell Anderson as "First Girl." After college she taught speech therapy at Martin Hall in Bristol, Rhode Island where she met her husband, Leo Greene. Greene was drafted and Hyalie often sent updates to the college bulletin to share their whereabouts. She taught speech therapy all her life and was also a long time member of Sakonet Preservation Association, serving as the Association Treasurer.

Gwendolyn \"Gwen\" Currier.bio: Gwendolyn Currier Jamieson was born on November 16, 1921 in Moulmein, Burma to Raymond Currier and Edith Gould. Her father was secretary to The American Mission to Lepers, Inc. and was located in Burma until Gwendolyn was two. She attended Westfield High School from 1936-1939, and then New Jersey College for Women from 1939-1941.

He also took coursework in dramatics throughout his three semesters at the college. He participated in at least three plays, where he is listed on the playbill. He joined the US Air Corps upon leaving the college and continued to write to the bulletin to share his experience through bootcamp and where he was stationed.

Dorothy \"Dottie\" Trayer.bio: Dorothy Trayer served as the College Registrar for a short stint, from late 1942 to early 1943. During that time, she sent correspondences for the Japanese-American student relocation program and studied piano under Frederic Cohen. She is noted to have held many performance with Cohen and performed on the BMC radio program regularly, while at the College. She was also noted as a secretary and listed as faculty wife in college bulletins.

Clara Gershkow.bio: Clara Gershkow Hofberg was born in Brooklyn, New York on January 22, 1918. Gershkow attended North High School in Minnesota from 1933 to 1935 and the University of Minnesota from 1938 to 1943. She also practiced music at MacPhail School of Music in Minneapolis, Minnesota and taught piano.

Elizabeth \"Slats\" Slater.bio: Elizabeth Jane Slater was a student at the college from 1940 to 1945. She was lovingly known by students and faculty as Jane, or “Slater,” “Slats,” “Slatso,” and other variations on her last name. She was very active in the arts and drama departments and spent time between the two, creating textiles and costumes for stage production. She worked in many mediums, including drawing, painting, graphic arts, weaving, and quilting.

David Sear.bio: David Sear (b. 1932) is a folk singer and radio host. He enrolled at Black Mountain College to record African American folk music in the area. He was befriended by the Reverend Laurence Daugherty and his Gospel Stars and traveled with them on tours. In New York, he formed a partnership Dillingham & Sear to tune and repair pianos, clavichords and harpsichords. His group, the American Folk Trio, brought folk music to children through the YoungAudiences programs mostly in the New York area, but also throughout the United States. He had a program, Adventures in Folk Music, on WNYC in which he combined folk and Baroque music. He later changed the title to Folk Music Almanac. He also ran a folk music concert series at the Spencertown Academy in Spencertown, New York.

Edgar Kaufmann, Jr..bio: Edgar Kaufmann, Jr. had a privileged childhood in Pittsburgh where his father owned Kaufmann's department store. He studied painting in New York, London, Vienna and Florence. On his return to the United States he was an apprentice at Frank Lloyd Wright's Taliesin from 1933-34. It was on a visit to his son that Kaufmann's father commissioned Wright to design his Bear Run home Fallingwater. Kaufmann worked for a time in his father's store in Pittsburgh.

She conducted a performance of Virgil Thompson’s The Mother of Us All at the University of California, San Diego in 1991.

Willem \"Bill\" de Kooning.bio: One of the most prominent and celebrated of the Abstract Expressionist painters, Willem de Kooning's pictures typify the vigorous, gestural style of the movement. Perhaps more than any of his contemporaries, he developed a radically abstract style of painting that fused Cubism, Surrealism and Expressionism. While many of his colleagues moved from figuration to abstraction, de Kooning always painted figures, most notably women, and abstractions concurrently, making no distinction between the art historical categories. De Kooning's real subject, he insisted, was space and the figure-ground relation. De Kooning fused abstraction, figuration, and landscapes in various ways throughout the many long decades of his career, and his unceasing journey to find new forms and subjects made his overall output more eclectic than most of his colleagues. His engagement with popular culture was also unique and informed a host of post-war artists from the Neo-Dadaism of Robert Rauschenberg to the Pop Art of James Rosenquist, and younger painters such as Cecily Brown have explored the gestural eroticism of his later paintings.

Adele Albert.bio: Adele Albert attended the college for the summer of 1944.
Adele Albert.courses_taken: Summer Session 1944: Cultural History (Bentley), Community Chorus (Jalowetz), English Literature (Kurtz), General Introduction to Sociology (Miller), Plato (Straus),Intro to Philosophy of Science (Straus), Drawing (Charlot)  A fantastic obituary was shared in her memory from Legacy.com, an excerpt can be seen here: Upon retiring from Fulton County (GA), she became an ardent activist. In 1984-85 she walked across the United States, as well as from Western Europe to Eastern Europe on the Walk for the People to promote peace and nuclear disarmament. Afterwards, she moved to the north Georgia mountains to continue her activism surrounded by nature. With her friend Joanne Steele, she co-founded ACE: Action for a Clean Environment, which waged successful campaigns against landfills and a medical incinerator, as well as raising awareness on many other environmental issues. An active member and for several years co-convener of the NE Georgia Peace Council, as well as WAND (Women's Action for Nuclear Disarmament), Nuclear Watch South, and the Workers Circle, Adele worked tirelessly for peace and justice. She was a frequent letter writer to local newspapers and participated in many demonstrations, some annually such as the Kings Bay Trident submarine base and the School for the Americas. She was an insatiable reader, devout vegetarian, and possessed a quick wit and superb intellect. An avid folk dancer, she credited dancing with preparing her well for her year and a half long Walk for the People. Having learned piano as a child, she maintained a love and practice of music, singing with the Atlanta Choral Guild under Robert Shaw and the Collegium Musicum community chorus at Emory University. In her 80s, she began painting in watercolors, writing poetry and her memoirs, and making spectacular mosaics.  Alternative Name: Adele Kushner

Henry \"Hal\" Adams, Jr..bio: Henry "Hal" Bethune Adams, Jr. was active at the College, giving weekly news commentaries to the study body and participating in many drama events. Henry’s senior examination records and some of his class writings are in his student file and show his love for writing. He joined the student body in the fall of 1942 and was drafted in 1943. While in the service, he regularly sent updates to the Community bulletins of his time away. Though there isn't much information accessible to share facts of his life while a student or shortly after, one can see that he had a love for storytelling when looking through the College bulletins. He even mentions in one that he was writing articles, essays, and fiction, and hoping to have someone look over his work. Henry returned to complete his senior evaluations at BMC until 1947. He requested transfer records from the college to be sent to the University of Chicago, University of Michigan, Duke University, and Harvard University in 1949. He wrote to the college in 1951 from Durham, NC so it is assumed that he attended Duke University for his MA. He asked for another round of transcripts to be sent in 1953 to Washington University, University of Kentucky, Purdue University, and the University of Buffalo where he wished to continue in the study of Psychology.

At the time of application, she listed employment as Assistant Department of Education, Museum of Modern Art.

Mary Dodge.bio: Mary Dodge attended the 1945 Summer Arts Institute, where she took Weaving with Anni Albers. She taught at Abbott Academy in Andover, Massachusetts.

Irma Wolpe.bio: Irma Wolpe Rademacher, née Schoenberg, was a Romanian-born American pianist and teacher. She taught music at BMC in the summer of 1953.

Lorna Blaine.bio: Lorna Blaine Howard Halper studied at Barnard College in New York before enrolling at Black Mountain College for the 1945 Summer Art Institute. She returned to the college in the winter of 1946 as a regular student and remained through the spring of 1948, except for the spring and summer 1947 terms. She studied with Josef Albers, Fannie Hillsmith, Robert Motherwell, Max Dehn and Ilya Bolotowsky, among others.

George Zabriske.bio: George Zabriskie taught writing at the college from the fall of 1944 to the summer of 1945. At the time of teaching at the colleg he held an A.B. from Duke University and authored "The Mind's Geography" while a Guggenheim fellow of poetry in 1942-43. Zabriskie went on to author many other books and collections of poems. There are many college bulletins that share his involvement in college activities, including weekly poetry readings for the students and faculty, and serving as fire chief on the Fire Committee. While chief, he did handle one large fire in 1944.

Victor Sprague.bio: Victor Sprague, a marine biologist and authority marine invertebrates and their parasites, taught biology at Black Mountain from the fall of 1951 through the fall of 1952. Spague obtained his Ph.D. from the University of Illinois and taught at several schools including Louisiana State University and Young Harris College. He served in the army during World War II. Before arriving at Black Mountain, he was head of the Parasitology Division, Project 9 at the Texas A&M Research Foundation.

Harold Anderson.bio: Harold Henry Anderson was a student at Black Mountain College for the fall semester of 1945. A recommendation letter from Mr. Erbie Bunten, of the Muskegon Public School system, shared that Harold was socialistic and an avid reader. He also shared that his family was religious and very active in the church, but that Harold held more scientific views. He had an interest in architecture and design. He was admitted as a student in the fall of 1945 and asked for a withdraw by mid-October.

In Vermont, she worked simultaneously as a taxi driver, driver of a senior transport van (she eventually had her own business), school bus driver, and driver for the University of Vermont (eventually working exclusively for the University).

Mary \"Mickey\" Miller.bio: Mickey Miller (1927-2001) received her B.A. from the University of California-Los Angeles. While at Black Mountain College in the fall of 1947, she collected folk songs in the area. Those songs are included in a recording titled Mickey Miller Sings American Folk Songs (Folkways Records FA 2393) (accompanied by Beth Lomax Hawes). She obtained her master’s degree in psychology and was instrumental in forming of the Topanga Center for Human Development.

Barbara \"Bobbie\" Dreier.bio: Like her husband, Barbara Loines Dreier was from a family of nonconformists, "un-regular" Christians," and adventurous thinkers. Her great-grandmother had fone to China on a clipper ship with an aunt and uncle and had stayed for five years. Her grandmother was a suffragist and a Unitarian, which Bobbie Dreier recalled "was as good as being a Communist in her day," and she married a Quaker, who was "read out of meeting for marrying such a radical girl." Two of her aunts became Christian Scientists, and her mother left the Episcopal Church after becoming interested in theosophy.

Horace \"Mac\" Wood.bio: Horace McGuire Wood came to Black Mountain College (Black Mountain, NC) in 1942 to become the school's business manager and director of the work experience program. He later taught design and construction courses. After they left the college in December 1945, Mr. and Mrs. Wood continued to live at their home in the town of Black Mountain, where he conducted a house planning and building seminar for many years. (Biographical note taken from the finding aid for the Horace McGuire Wood Papers, 1933 - 1972, North Carolina State Archives.)

Heinz Oberlander.bio: Peter Oberlander (1922-2008) was a Canadian architect and Canada’s first professor of urban and regional planning. He obtained his Bachelor of Architecture degree from McGill University and his Master of Urban Planning and Ph.D. in Urban and Regional Planning from Harvard University. At Harvard, Walter Gropius suggested that Oberlander and fellow student Harry Seidler enroll for the 1946 Summer Art Institute at Black Mountain College to study with Josef Albers. At the University of British Columbia, Oberlander established Canada’s first department of Urban and Regional Planning. In Ottawa, he initiated the federal government’s Ministry of Urban Affairs. With his support and encouragement, the United Nations World Urban Forum III was held in Vancouver in 2006. Posthumously, he was awarded the United Nations Scroll of Honour Award on World Habitat Day, October 4, 2009.

However, I used to have a great interest in numbers (progressions, factors, etc.). Also I was very much interested in the populations of cities, particularly those in the United States.”

Ernst Bacon.bio: Ernst Bacon was an acclaimed American composer, pianist, and conductor. Born in Chicago, Bacon attended Northwestern University, the University of Chicago, and the University of California, Berkeley. Although mostly self-taught as a composer, he studied briefly with Karl Weigl in Vienna, Austria. He was on the faculty of the Eastman School of Music and the San Francisco Conservatory of Music and was appointed to head the WPA Music Project in San Francisco. He also founded the Carmel Bach Festival. His chief teaching positions were at Converse College in Spartanburg, SC (1938-45) and Syracuse University (1945-64), where he retired as Professor Emeritus.

Mary Washington.bio: Mary Parks Washington heard about Black Mountain at the end of her senior year at Spelman College in Atlanta where she majored in art. The college had enrolled its first black students in the summer of 1944, and Washington remembered that althoughthe South was still segregated, she felt comfortable attending.

Fernando \"Paco\" Leon.bio: Fernando Leon (1919-2009) was an engineer. Before immigrating to the United States, he and his brother Francisco “Paco” Leon fought with the resistance in Spain in the Spanish Civil War. Francisco, who died from tuberculosis which he contracted in the war, also enrolled at Black Mountain College (BMC). Leon received his B.S. in engineering from Columbia University and his Master of Automotive Engineering from the Chrysler Institute. He worked at Chrysler on development of the XIV-2220 aircraft engine and was a founder of FOREL Equipment Co. in New York City, an exporter of steelmaking and metalworking equipment which helped set up industrial plants in Latin America and Europe under the Marshall Plan. Later he founded Om-El Corporation in Bay City, Michigan, with similar activities as FOREL. Leon was a trustee for Marlboro College in Vermont where Roland Boyden, a former BMC teacher, served in many roles. Leon was married to BMC student Eleanor “Elie” Smith Leon.

Leonard \"Knute\" Stiles.bio: Knute Stiles (1923-2009) was a painter, collagist, art critic, and writer. During World War II, he served in Alaska and thereafter spent summers working on salmon boats and organizing workers. He enrolled at Black Mountain College in 1946 and studied with Ilya Bolotowsky. In San Francisco, he was briefly co-owner with Leo Krikorian of The Place, an influential bar in San Francisco’s North Beach district that was a gathering place for Beat writers and artists. Stiles taught drawing at the San Francisco Art Institute and wrote criticism for Art Forum and Art in America. He was a founder and member of San Francisco’s East-West House, a communal living space, where many artists and writers lived.

Gertrud \"Trude\" Guermonprez.bio: Trude Jalowetz Guermonprez was born in Danzig, Germany and attended the School of Fine and Applied Arts in Halle-Saale, where she studied weaving under the Bauhaus-trained artist Benita Otte. In 1933, she earned a professional diploma from the Textile Engineering School in Berlin and received a fellowship to study Scandinavian weaving in Sweden and Finland. Upon completion of her studies, Guermonprez moved to Holland where she continued to foster her understanding of technical weave structures and patterns, working for the Dutch hand weaving production studio Het Paapje.

Olivia Silberberg.bio: Olivia Silberberg Toubman (1921-2020) was cellist with the Oklahoma Symphony Orchestra when she was invited to perform at the 1949 summer session at BMC. The four Silberberg sisters formed the Silberberg String Quartette, which performed in the Boston and Worcester area. Concetta Scaravaglione.bio: Concetta Scaravaglione was guest faculty of sculpture at the 1946 Summer Art Institute. Scaravaglione had a long career a sculptor and teacher. While she worked in wood, stone, bronze, and copper, her preferred media was terra-cotta. As her work evolved, it became more abstract.

Jane Bartoli.bio: Jane Bartoli was a pianist and gave lecture recitals on the development of the piano-violin sonata and lead string ensembles in the summer of 1947. She studied at University of Pittsburgh. She was a concert pianist, having played in Carnegie Hall. She married Lino Bartoli, a Pittsburgh Symphony violinist and moved to Texas when Lino accepted Baylor University professorship.

Peter \"Pete\" Heinemann.bio: Peter was a student at the college from 1948 to 1949. Before BMC, he attended Windsor Mountain School. After college, he taught painting at the School for the Visual Arts in New York.

Howard \"Rondy\" Rondthaler.bio: Howard Rondthaler was a student from 1952 to 1955 and family to faculty members. He graduated with a concentration of writing and literature with examiner, Robert Creeley.
Howard \"Rondy\" Rondthaler.relations: Parent: Theodore Edward Rondthaler, Parent: Alice Katherine Rondthaler, Mary Emma Harris interviewed Howard in 1997 and the transcript is available from Appalachian State University under The Mary Emma Harris and Black Mountain College Project, Inc. Oral History collection.: transcript

Eleanore Bermann.bio: Eleanore Bermann was born in New York, New York. She was only sixteen when she enrolled at Black Mountain College for the 1945 Summer Art Institute where she studied with Josef Albers, Lyonel Feininger, Fannie Hillsmith, Robert Motherwell, and Ossip Zadkine.

Irene Simon.bio: Irene Simon was a student for the 1944 Summer Art institute.

Ralph Beckley.bio: Ralph wrote to the college for nearly three years asking for financial aid so he could attend. It wasn't until December of 1937 that his aid request was granted. He took coursework in literature and applied for senior examinations multiple times and was not admitted. After his third attempt, he left the college.

Nikolai Graudan.bio: Nikolai Graudan was a cellist and guest faculty of music for the summer of 1944.

Julia Light.bio: Julia Light was a student from fall 1947 to spring 1949.

Alvin Freeman.bio: Alvin Freeman was a history professor from 1949 to 1950.

David Stetzel.bio: David Stetzel was a student in 1950.

Margaret \"Peggy\" Vaughan.bio: Peggy Vaughan was a student in 1948.

Robert Goehring.bio: Robert was a student for fall 1940.
Robert Goehring.courses_taken: Fall 1940-1941: Readings in Literature with Kurtz, Introductory Writing withWunsch, Contemporary Architecture with Kocher, Advanced German withStraus, Chorus with Jalowetz

Morris \"Mouse\" Simon.bio: Morris “Mouse” Simon was a student at Black Mountain College from 1940-1941. He grew up in Union City, New Jersey where his father had a haberdashery. He took a general curriculum including mathematics, political theory, drama, literature and art.

Edwin \"Eddie\" Woldin.bio: Judd Woldin grew up in Somerville, New Jersey, where his father worked in the family shoe store. In the fall of 1944, he enrolled at Black Mountain College to study with the composer Heinrich Jalowetz. He completed that year at the college and enrolled for the 1945-46 fall and winter quarters.

Syril Bright.bio: Sybil Bright was a student for the summer of 1953. She was interested in studying with Wesley Huss. After attending BMC, she was a secretary for Temple University.

Leo Lionni.bio: Leo Lionni, a painter, sculptor, graphic designer, educator, and writer and illustrator of children’s books, was a member of the summer arts faculty at Black Mountain College in 1946. Lionni was born in Amsterdam, Holland in 1910 to an Italian family.

Ren\u00e9 Pinchuk.bio: René Pinchuk was a student for the summer of 1946. He graduated from Cass Technical High School in Detroit and friend and fellow BMC student, Ray Johnson recommended he come to BMC. After leaving, he attended Wayne State University and received a degree in design.

Homer Boblin.bio: Homer was a student for the fall of 1942. He shared in his application that he was interested in gaining "a thorough business education and a broad cultural backgorund." He had just graduated high school when applying and all of his reference mention that he is shy and timid, but a good student.
Homer Boblin.relations: Wife, Fellow BMC student, Elizabeth Ferris Kelley: Elizabeth Ferris Kelley

Eduard Steuermann.bio: Eduard Steuermann was guest faculty of music in the summer of 1944. Steuermann studied piano with Vilém Kurz at the Lemberg Conservatory and Ferruccio Busoni in Berlin, and studied composition with Engelbert Humperdinck and Arnold Schoenberg.

William Hinckley.bio: William Hinckley was founding faculty in psychology that came from Rollins College. He received his BA from Rollins College in 1931 and taught at BMC from fall 1933 to fall 1934.

Peter Nemenyi.bio: Peter Nemenyi was a student from summer 1947 to spring 1950. He became a well known mathematician working in statistics and probability theory, and also an activist.

Wilfrid \"Will\" Hamlin.bio: Will Hamlin was a student at the college from 1940 to 1942. He also served as Guest Faculty, worked in the Print Shop, was active in the work camp, and participated in the College Publicity Bureau.
Wilfrid \"Will\" Hamlin.relations: Wife: Betty Brett, Mary Emma Harris interviewed Will in 1997 and the transcript is available from Appalachian State University under The Mary Emma Harris and Black Mountain College Project, Inc. Oral History collection.: transcript

Nataraj Vashi.bio: Nataraj Vashi was guest faculty in dance and Hindu philosophy for the Summer Art Institute of 1949.

Dorothy Cole.bio: Dorothy was a student from the fall of 1945 to the spring of 1947. While a student, she participated in student concerts and worked in the music library. She took a range of coursework in the arts, music, and social sciences. All of her faculty notes were very positive, across all subjects, and Josef Albers was especially impressed in her work. After her time at BMC, she went on to do illustrations and textile design.

Walter \"WC\" Barnes.bio: Walter C. Barnes was an educator in the fields of Modern European History, English History, Russian, China, and Japan. Barnes regularly published on topics related to Soviet Russia, and historical topics for Events and the Journal of Modern History. He taught History at the college from the fall of 1938 to the spring of 1941.

Roger Sessions.bio: Roger Sessions was guest faculty of music in the summer of 1944. Sessions was an American composer, teacher, and writer on music. He had initially started his career writing in a neoclassical style, but gradually moved further towards more complex harmonies and postromanticism, and finally the twelve-tone serialism of the Second Viennese School.

Theodoros Stamos.bio: Theodoros Stamos was guest faculty of painting and drawing in 1950.

Francis \"Faf\" Foster.bio: Francis Arthur Foster attended the college from the winter of 1941 to the summer of 1948. He left the college around 1945 to serve in the Army and work with the Red Cross and then returned to graduate after his service.

Dorothy Carr.bio: Dorothy Carr was a student from fall of 1944 to spring of 1946. She took Introductory Weaving with Anni Albers (and student teacher Marilyn Bauer) in the fall of 1944.Within that time she took a leave of absence for at least the fall semester of 1945. While a student, she was part of the ladder crew, fire committee, and regularly played the viola for the student body.

Karl Niebyl.bio: Karl Niebyl taught economics from spring 1946 to summer 1951. Niebyl came to the United States in 1934, after escaping from Nazi Germany.

Wanda Shult.bio: Wanda Shult was a student in spring of 1948.

Rudolf Kolisch.bio: Rudolf Kolisch was a Viennese violinist and leader of string quartets, including the Kolisch Quartet and the Pro Arte Quartet. He was guest faculty of music for the Summer Music Institute of 1944.

Alice Rondthaler.bio: Alice Rondthaler (1945-1948) was a typing and shorthand tutor from the 1945 summer session to the 1948 summer session.
Alice Rondthaler.relations: Husband: Theodore Edward Rondthaler, Child: Howard Mayro Rondthaler, Mary Emma Harris interviewed Alice in 1997 and the transcript is available from Appalachian State University under The Mary Emma Harris and Black Mountain College Project, Inc. Henry Black.bio: Henry Black was a student at the college for the summer of 1943. He immigrated from Germany and his original name was Heinz Schwarzchild.

Eva Heinetz.bio: Eva Heinitz was a German musician, best known as a cellist but also highly acclaimed for her recordings on the viola da gamba. She was a guest faculty in music at the Summer Music Institute of 1945.

Sydney Irwin.bio: Sydney Irwin was a student at the college.

John Corrington.bio: John Corrington was a student at the college from 1945 to 1946. He is mentioned in college bulletins doing public play readings for the student body.

Stuart \"Squeaky\" Atkinson.bio: Stuart Atkinson was a student at the college from the spring of 1945 to the spring of 1947. While a student, he was involved in the French Club and served as the Fire Chief. Students and faculty referred to Stuart as "Squeaky."

Maryrose Margaretten.bio: Maryrose Margaretten was a student from 1947 to 1948.

Theodore \"Ted\" Dreier.bio: Theodore “Ted” Dreier was the son of a prominent family of idealists committed to the arts, social action, women’s rights, and poverty programs. Ted studied electrical engineering at Harvard University from 1920-1925 then worked at General Electric until 1930. A friend, John Malcolm Forbes, brought Dreier to Rollins College where he taught until 1933. Along with the group of staff that left Rollins with John Andrew Rice, he then joined the founding faculty of Black Mountain College in the summer of 1933.

Carl Clement.bio: Carl Clement was a guest faculty in physics during the summer of 1947.

Carol Brice.bio: Carol Brice was guest faculty and performer for many summer Music Institutes; including 1945 Summer Session Performer and Guest Faculty, 1947 Summer Session performer, 1950-1951 Guest Faculty, and 1952-1953 Guest Faculty.

Elizabeth \"Betty\" Mosley.bio: Elizabeth Mosely was secretary at the college for the 1941-1942 school year.

Louise Hetherington.bio: Louise Hetherington was faculty of music from fall 1949 to fall 1951.

Elaine Schmitt.bio: As a child Elaine Schmitt (Urbain), who was born in 1925 in Wauwatosa, Wisconsin, was frequently at Conrad Schmitt Stained Glass Studios, founded by her grandfather in 1885 in Milwaukee. Urbain, along with her siblings, helped in the Studios and was exposed to art at an early age.

Elizabeth Estill.bio: Elizabeth was a librarian at the college and attended a two-week ceramics course in the summer of 1954.

Peggy Bennett.bio: Peggy Bennett was a student at the college from the fall of 1944 to the spring of 1945. She was very interested in writing and studying in a place that would allow her to be introduced to knew things, so she could write about the experiences.

Dorothy Darrell.bio: Dorothy Darrell was a student in the summer and fall of 1953.

Jsrael \"J.B.\" Neumann.bio: J.B. Neumann taught art appreciation in the 1944 Summer Art Institute. J.B. was a gallery director, art dealer and publisher. After immigrating to the U.S., Neumann founded the New Art Circle Gallery in New York City. Before then, he had art galleries in Berlin, Munich, Dusseldorf and Bremen, Germany.

Ronald Robertson.bio: Ronald Robertson enrolled at Black Mountain College for the1951 summer and fall terms. There he studied painting and drawing with Ben Shahn and Robert Motherwell.

Dorothy Breeskin.bio: Dorothy Breeskin attended the 1944 Music Institute, along with her mother (Adelyn Dohme Breeskin) and two sisters. She participated in the New England Conservatory of Music, and is noted as cellist and acapella singer.
Dorothy Breeskin.relations: Husband: Samuel Emmons Brown, Jr., Mother: Adelyn Breeskin, Sister: Gloria Breeskin

Lorraine Creesy.bio: Lorraine was a student from spring 1938 to spring 1940. Lorraine married Leon Wilbur Miller.

Fall semester, 1939-40: Psychological Problems (Straus), The Novel (Kurtz), Werklehre (Albers), Music (Evarts), Chorus (Jalowetz). Spring semester, 1939-40: Psychological Problems (Straus), The English Novel (Kurtz), Music (Evarts), Chorus (Jalowetz), Play Production (Wunsch).

Robert Babcock.bio: Robert Babcock was an educator and politician, that served as a Vermont senate from 1951 to 1955. At Black Mountain College, he taught government and politics from 1940 to 1942. He left in 1942 to work at the United States Department of Treasury as a commercial control specialist. After serving in the Navy during World War II, he returned to teaching at the University of Vermont and obtained his PhD from Northwestern University.

Donald Cooper.bio: Donald Cooper was a student at the college in fall of 1952 to summer 1954.

Monika L\u00e1nyi-Mann.bio: Monika Lányi-Mann was a student in the fall of 1944. She became a well-known author and feature writer and the the fourth of six children of the Nobel Prize–winning author Thomas Mann.

Helen \"Helsie\" Wright.bio: Helen Wright was a student at the college from 1941 to 1945. She took Introductory to Advanced Weaving with Anni Albers, 1942-1944. She participated in the membership committee, and in many plays,. In 1945 she worked as an office secretary.

Dorothy Ball.bio: Dorothy Ball applied to Black Mountain so she could work on her German writing and "conversation." She was attending another school and had a language requirement to meet, but she was deaf. Her application shares that her "lip reading" was not sufficient enough in German and she was looking for opportunities to improve that skill.

Mollie Boring.bio: Mollie Boring was a student at the college for three semester from 1943 through 1944. She took general coursework in all fields and her reports stated that she was unhappy and oftentimes resentful to authority and social interactions on campus. These issues were shared in a letter to her parents and she ultimately left BMC to attend Bard College.

Andrew \"Andy\" Oates, Jr.bio: Andrew “Andy” Oates was raised in Graniteville, Rhode Island. He served in the Pacific Theater in the Navy during World War II and later graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design.

Frank Rice.bio: Frank Aydelotte Rice, son of John Rice, founder of the college, arrived at Black Mountain College with his family in 1933. He was a student there from 1934 to 1937.

Massen Noland.bio: Neil Noland (1927-2013) was the youngest of the three Noland brothers — Harry, Ken and Neil — who enrolled at Black Mountain College (BMC). Noland took a general curriculum with an emphasis on art, music and ceramics. He left to spend a year in Europe on the GI Bill. After a time in Washington D.C., he moved to New York and studied ceramics at Greenwich House while supporting himself working for newspapers and the Arab Information Center. In ceramics,he explored the fish form as an avenue to abstraction. In Amagansett, he worked in various media, including metal and fiberglass.

Nathaniel \"Nat\" Lytle.bio: Nat Lytle was a Black Mountain native (raised in Black Mountain and Asheville) who worked for Black Mountain College for over a decade. In the summers of 1933 and 1934, Nat Lytle worked odd jobs and some cooking at the college. From 1937-1938, he worked as an assistant cook, under Jack and Rubye Lipsey, in the kitchen. After three years in the army, he returned to the college from 1944-1946 and worked in the kitchen and on odd jobs. On Tuesdays, the day off for cooks Cornelia and George Williams, Nat Lytle would help remaining cook Malrey Few with the cooking.

Eva Schlein.bio: Eva Schlein Jungermann, born in Furth (Bavaria) Germany in 1923, was one of a number of refugee students at Black Mountain. She was enrolled at the college for the 1945 spring quarter, the 1945-46 academic year and the 1946 fall session. She also attended the 1945 summer session. Her primary interests were writing, philosophy, psychology, and history. While at BMC, she worked in the library.

James Herlihy.bio: James was a student at the college from fall of 1947 to summer of 1948. In a college bulletin, he was mentioned in another student's updates "James Herlihy is at the Pasadena Playhouse, acting and writing plays."

Frank Hursh, Jr..bio: Frank Hursh (b. 1929) is an artist, educator, and animator. Hursh enrolled at Black Mountain College in 1949 to study art. He earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree at the University of Texas at Austin. Hursh used his G.I. Bill benefits after service in the United States Navy to continue his studies in Mexico. Finding his budding career to be more interesting than his academic studies, he pursued his interests as a freelance commercial artistand animator. At Gamma Studios, he was involved in productions, including Rocky and His Friends (Rocky and Bullwinkle). He taught at the Instituto Allende in San Miguel de Allende, Guanajuato. In Querétaro, he created the arts program at the new campus of the Universidad del Valle de México. Hursh’s paintings and drawings are in an Abstract Expressionist style.

The Time dance-drama was very exciting: text by John Reiss, read by Tommie Cutshaw; choreography by Molly Gregory and Patsy Lynch, with the aid of Don Wight and Jose Yglesias; to the beat of Jimmy Tite’s drums."  2017.30.219 November 1946 bulletin, "Willi Joseph, Joan Sihvenen and Don Wight are working on large looms. The paintings were composed from sketches done in the Jean Varda painting class in the summer Art Institute. After this exhibition, Don Wight planned record concerts and art showings for Sunday evenings in the art room."  2017.40.246 Exhibit of Evolution of Housing Plans of BMC, 1946 "TRANSITION June 1946 Material Exhibited: Drawings of small study-dormitory unit by Don Wight As a result of plans for a small dormitory designed by Don Wight with the collaboration of several other students, the question of the most appropriate size for a new dormitory was re-opened. It was also suggested that studies and sleeping quarters be combined in small units, as shown in Don Wight’s drawings. After much discussion, the latter idea was rejected, but as the consensus of opinion in the community was strongly in favor of a small dormitory to be built first rather than a large one, the campaign to raise funds for the latter was suspended and the whole matter postponed until a new plan could be made."

Wilma Stokely.bio: Wilma Dykeman (1920-2006) was a writer of fiction and non-fiction who chronicled the culture of Appalachia in Western North Carolina. Her three novels are The Tall Woman (1962), The Far Family (1966) and Return of the Innocent Earth (1973). Her non-fiction books include The French Broad (1955), and Prophet of Plenty: the First Ninety Years of Willis Weatherford. In the fall of 1944, at Black Mountain College, she and her husband James Dykeman audited classes taught by Alfred Kazin as well as a class taught by poet George Zabriskie, in the fall of 1944.

She married Simon Goldberg and devoted her life to raising her children and participating with nonprofit organizations.

Thomas \"Tom\" Nee.bio: Thomas “Tom” Nee (1920- 2008) enrolled at Black Mountain College (BMC) to study with composer Stefan Wolpe. Nee was chair of the department of music at the University of California at San Diego where he developed an innovative contemporary music curriculum. He was artistic director and conductor of the La Jolla Symphony for thirty-one years and director of the New Hampshire Music Festival from 1960 until 1992.

Paul Alexander.bio: Paul Alexander (1931-2021) enrolled at Black Mountain College for its last full academic year, 1955-1956. He had to leave before the end of the year when GI Bill benefits were cut. He settled in San Francisco where he was a central figure in the San Francisco Renaissance. He operated Buzz Gallery and held various jobs, including working for Southern Pacific railroad and in the modern art department at Gump’s. He lived in Fort Bragg in MendocinoCounty in the final years of his life.

Marcel Dick.bio: Marcel Dick was a viola and violin player and had a prominent performing career in Europe with string quartets and orchestras before immigrating to the United States. In Europe, he was a member of the Schoenberg Circle and was invited to perform with Rudolf Kolisch’s summer quartet at Black Mountain College. He was head of the graduate department of theory and composition at the Cleveland Institute of Music and principal violinist with the Cleveland Orchestra.

Sarah Towery.bio: Sarah Carlisle Towery was a student at Black Mountain College during the 1944 Summer Art Institute. A painter and teacher, she conducted kindergarten and art classes in her home for fifty years. To celebrate her eightieth birthday, in October 1992, her children organized a gathering of professional friends with whom she had studied and painted over many years. That gathering was the catalyst for the Sarah Carlisle Towery/Alabama Art Colony on Lake Martin in Alexander City.

He interrupted his studies to serve in the United States Navy. Patricia Nelson.bio: Patricia Nelson Newhall (1933-2016) was a psychiatrist. In New York after leaving Black Mountain College (BMC), she worked at Motorcycles Incorporated, a shop in New York owned by her future husband Daniel Newhall and a place where other BMC students worked. Newhall studied at City College of New York and Temple University. She earned her medical degree from Women’s Medical College of Philadelphia and graduated from the Philadelphia Psychoanalytic Society. She graduated Summa cum Laude at the Tyler Art School of Art and Architecture where she majored in sculpture.

Raymond \"Ray\" Toubman.bio: Raymond Toubman (1921-2009) was first oboist with the Oklahoma Symphony Orchestra when he was invited to perform at the 1949 summer session at Black Mountain College (BMC). During his career, he was first oboist with the Indianapolis Symphony, the Southern Symphony Orchestra, and the Atlanta Symphony. He performed with the Boston Pops Orchestra under Arthur Fielder and with many Boston organizations. Toubman obtained his master’s degree in library science and his Ph.D. in musicology from Boston University. While working as librarian at the Oglethorpe University Library, Toubman performed as a freelance musician.

Stefan Wolpe.bio: Stefan Wolpe was a German-born American composer. He was associated with interdisciplinary modernism, with affiliations ranging from the Bauhaus, Berlin agitprop theater and the kibbutz movement to the Eighth Street Artists' Club, Black Mountain College, and the Darmstadt Summer Courses for New Music.

Franz Kline.bio: Franz Kline was an American painter associated with the Abstract Expressionist movement of the 1940s and 1950s. Kline is best known for his powerful black-and-white abstractions in which the vigorous brushwork seems to embody the energy and gestures created in the act of painting.

Marie Tavroges.bio: Marie Tavroges Stillkind was a student at Black Mountain College in the spring to summer of 1952. A native of Montreal, she had studied art at Sir George Williams College in Montreal, where she met Dorothea Rockburne, a Black Mountain student.

Emanuel Zetlin.bio: Emanuel Zetlin taught music at the Summer Music Institute of 1945. While at the college, he shared that he was Associate Concertmaster of the Metropolitan Opera Company and a member of the faculty of the Manhattan School of Music. Zetlin's name can be found in many concert posters and college bulletins for the summer of 1945 for his violin performances.

Boris Aronson.bio: Boris Solomon Aronson was a scenic designer, occasional costume designer, painter and sculptor. He was born around 1900 in Kiev (currently the independent Ukraine), the son of a rabbi, and came of age during the Russian Revolution. He studied art and design at the School of Modern Painting in Moscow, as well as studying with the avant-garde painter and stage designer Alexandra Exter.

Martha Hult.bio: Martha Hult was a student in 1946. Before BMC, she attended Reed College in Portland, OR.

Jeanne Wacker.bio: Jeanne Wacker was a very involved student. She was involved in the International Relations Club which held public debates about current topics. She was also involved in drama productions. She was also involved in student activities on the farm and in the kitchen, helping to organize student duties and responsibilities.

He participated in plays, such as Outward Bound, and The Importance of Being Earnest. He asked for transcripts to be sent to Bard College and Columbia upon leaving BMC. According to Mary Emma Harris' interview with Addison, he taught a general curriculum in New York City high schools, primarily in Harlem.

Elizabeth \"Lisa\" Jalowetz.bio: Lisa Jalowetz Aronson (1920-2013) was a stage designer and collaborator with Boris Aronson for major Broadway productions including A Little Night Music, Fiddler on the Roof, The Crucible and many others. She worked with notable theater persons including Harry Horner and Norman Bel Geddes. She collaborated with Frank Rich on The Theatre of Boris Aronson, documenting his work as a stage designer. As daughter of conductor Heinrich Jalowetz, she spent her childhood in Austria and Germany. When the Nazis invaded Vienna where she was a student, she escaped to Holland. A student visa from Black Mountain College where her father had been appointed enabled her to immigrate to the United States.

William Miller.bio: William Blackall Miller (1916-2004) graduated in art history from Harvard University and received his Ph.D. from Columbia University. He taught at the Rhode Island School of Design, Milton Academy, Amherst College, and Colby College. Miller, besides being an artist, was an accomplished calligrapher and a pop craftsman creating limericks, whirligigs, hand bound books, toys and puzzles. He spent a year in Rome on a Fulbright Scholarship and traveled widely. He was active in the Maine League of Historical Societies and Museums and other preservation organizations.

John Rice.bio: John Andrew Rice was an educator and founder of Black Mountain College. He was born and raised in South Carolina; his father was a Methodist minister and college educator, and his mother was sister to U.S. Senator, Ellison Durant “Cotton Ed” Smith. Rice attended the Webb School in Tennessee, a college preparatory boarding school, and Tulane University in New Orleans, where he graduated with a bachelors in classics in just three years. He was awarded a Rhodes Scholarship in 1911, attended Oxford University until 1914, and was a doctoral student in classics from the University of Chicago from 1916 to 1917.

Claude Stoller.bio: Claude Stoller was an architect of note, known for his advocacy for social housing and historic preservation. He grew up in the Bronx, New York. Stoller's completion of studies at DeWitt Clinton High School, coincided with the exhibit Bauhaus 1919-1928 at the Museum of Modern Art. Through this exhibition, he became interested in attending Black Mountain College (BMC) in western North Carolina. While at BMC, Stoller took a wide variety of classes, including Josef Albers's courses in design, color, and drawing along with architecture courses led by Lawrence Kocher, Howard Dearstyne, and Lou Bernard Voight. Stoller, along with fellow student Charles Forberg, oversaw the construction of the Jalowetz House, a small dwelling designed by Lawrence Kocher for music instructor Henrich Jalowetz, and his family. BMC also gave Stoller a chance to experiment with photography. In 1942, Claude Stoller was drafted into the United States Army. He served in the 14th Coast Artillery on Puget Sound in Washington State. After attending army engineering school, Stoller served in Germany and France with the 13th Armored Division.

Jennerjahn, Color with Jennerjahn, Textile Design, Weaving with Oates Summer 1951: Dance with Litz  Obituary: Adele LaBrecque during her nearly 94 years studied art at Black Mountain College in North Carolina, danced the flamenco in New York City, and journeyed to Dharan, Saudi Arabia, as a single woman in the 1950s to work in public relations for Aramco Oil Co. She was just getting started. From there, she married Maurice LaBrecque, who she met in Dharan, had two sons – Louis and Mark – and lived in Tripoli, Libya, from 1966 to 1984 during a time of immense change in the country. The family traveled widely, and Adele immersed herself in her art, whether it was painting scenes of everyday life in Saudi Arabia or filming and acting as editor and producer of homemade documentary films in both Saudi Arabia and Libya. Adele and Maury moved to Winston-Salem, N.C., after leaving Libya following Maury’s retirement, and Adele ultimately worked in Wake Forest University’s alumni office until her own retirement in early 1999, more than nine years after her husband’s death in December 1989. At that point, she headed to Santa Fe, a place where she felt completely at home. Volunteer work was a given for Adele, and she put her talents to use at a variety of organizations, including the Santa Fe Opera and the Lensic Performing Arts Center. Adele continued to paint and found a wonderful group of friends who enriched her life.

Alma Stone Williams.bio: Alma Stone Williams was a musician, educator, music scholar, and pioneer in racial integration. Williams attended the 1944 Summer Music Institute. Her tuition was covered through the Rosenwald Fund, which also paid her way through Juliard. She was already a music teacher at Fort Valley State College when she applied to BMC. She also obtained a masters in musicology at the University of Maryland where she focused on the works of Brahms.

Leo Amino.bio: Leo Amino—born in Taiwan in 1911 where his father was an agricultural consultant for the Japanese government—was reared in Tokyo. In 1929, he immigrated to the United States and studied at San Mateo Junior College in California for two years and, later, at New York University. He remained in New York to work for a Japanese wood importing firm and took home ebony samples to carve. Although he had received no formal art training, his interest in sculpture grew rapidly and, in 1937, he studied briefly at the American Artists School with Chaim Gross, a leading proponent of direct carving.

Caroline Ewing.bio: Caroline Burton Michahelles (b. 1929) was a real estate agent, an artist, and a poet. She attended the University of Pennsylvania where she majored in philosophy and the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. After her marriage to Nicolo Michahelles, she lived in Connecticut and Italy. In 1973, she organized an influential exhibition of American artists in Europe at the Palazzo Pretorio in Prato, Tuscany, Italy. After her children were grown, she focused on her painting. Her poetry has been published as Nonsense-no Poems.

Harriet Florence Sohmers.bio: Harriet Sohmers Zwerling (1928-2019) was a writer, editor, and artist’s model. In Paris in the 1950s, she was associated with the expatriate scene and later part of the literary scene in New York. She was an artist’s model for painters. While a student at Berkeley, she was a friend of Peggy Tolk-Watkins, owner of the Tin Angel, a jazz and crab bar in Sausalito. She obtained her B.A. from Hunter College and, after her marriage to Louis Zwerling,taught elementary school in Brooklyn, New York, for twenty-eight years. She was bisexual and had affairs with Susan Sontag, Irene Fornés and others. Her memoir Notes of a Nude Model and Other Pieces was published in 2003. She appears in the documentary Still Doing It about the sex lives of older women.

Etta Mandelbaum.bio: Etta Deikman notably studied painting with Hans Hoffman at his School of Art in New York City. While at Black Mountain College in the 1948 summer session, she studied painting with Willem de Kooning and sculpture with Peter Grippe. She was there for the legendary summer of John Cage, Merce Cunningham, and Buckminster Fuller who were also brought on by Josef Albers to teach. Deikman approaches each painting as an adventurous journey, finding surprising relationships and ideas as she goes; this sort of freedom of thought and acceptance of chance aligns with the way students were taught at Black Mountain College.

Edward \"Ed\" Dorn.bio: Edward Dorn was a poet and teacher. Studied at the University of Illinois and at Black Mountain College (1950-1955). At Black Mountain he came into contact with Charles Olson, who greatly influenced his literary worldview and his sense of himself as poet. Dorn's final examiner at Black Mountain was Robert Creeley (q.v.), with whom, along with the poet Robert Duncan, Dorn became included as one of a trio of younger poets later associated with Black Mountain and with Charles Olson. Joined the teaching staff at the University of Essex in 1965. He spent most of the next five years in England, where he published several collections of poems and wrote Book 1 of of his most famous poem 'Gunslinger'

Annelise \"Anni\" Albers.bio: Annelise Elsa Freida Fleischmann was born in Berlin, Germany in 1899 and grew up in a comfortable well-to-do family. Her father worked as a furniture maker. Intrigued with design and aesthetics at an early age, she became interested in the idea of becoming an artist. In 1922, she enrolled at the Bauhaus in Weimar. Although originally interested in painting, she was steered towards textiles, as were most women.

Hazel Larsen.bio: Hazel Larsen Archer experienced life at BMC as a student, faculty, and as a staff member working in the college office. She studied art, design, and photography, taking classes with Josef Albers, Josef Breitenbach, and Beaumont Newhall among others. Starting in 1949, Hazel was appointed to teach photography, and was at the college for nine years altogether. As many of her students later stated, Hazel had a lasting impact on them with her emphasis on seeing rather than technique. She also invited photographers to teach at Black Mountain College including Harry Callahan, Aaron Siskind, and Arthur Siegel for a special focus on photography in the summer of 1951.

Donald \"Don\" Alter.bio: Donald Alter shared in his application, “by attending Black Mountain College I hope to help myself become more mundane. In the final analysis I believe that all the things I hope to gain at Black Mountain would help me to become a more aware and more worthwhile artist. From the information I have gathered about Black Mountain I have concluded that the program offered is conductive to the afore said.”

Spring 1933-1934: Music Appreciation with Evarts, French conversation with Keith, Drawing with Albers and Greek History and Humanism with Boyden. Fall 1935-1936 [note year gap]: Survey of French Literature with Mangold, Creative Writing with Wunsch, Drawing II with Albers, MusicAppreciation with Evarts, Plato II with Rice, and teaching shop 2 days a week. Spring 1935-1936: Survey of French Literature with Mangold, Play Writing with Wunsch, Plato II with Rice, Music II with Evarts, Shakespeare and Elizabethan Drama with Martin and Wunsch, Teaching at cottage school two days per week. Fall 1936-1937: U.S. History with King, 17th Century English literature with Martin, Dramatics II with Wunsch, England since 1485 with King. Spring 1936-1937: American History with King, Contemporary American Literature with Wunsch, Dramatics II with Wunsch, Survey of English Literature with Martin. Fall 1937-1938: Writing Seminar with Rice, Dramatics II and III with Wunsch, American Literature Tutorial with Wunsch. Spring 1937-1938: Dramatics II with Wunsch, Seminar inAmerican Literature with Surette, Writing Seminar with Rice, Tutorial inAmerican Literature with Wunsch.

Erwin Straus.bio: Erwin Straus was a German-American phenomenologist and neurologist who helped to pioneer anthropological medicine and psychiatry, a holistic approach to medicine that is critical of mechanistic and reductionistic approaches to understanding and treating human beings.

John Cage.bio: John Cage was a composer and music theorist who was guest faculty at Black Mountain College from 1948 to 1953. He is known for his avant-garde compositions and the famous Theatre Piece No. 1 (1952), considered the first Happening.

Anni Albers.bio: Anni Albers was a textile artist and printmaker who served as faculty at Black Mountain College from 1933 to 1949. She arrived with her husband Josef Albers from Germany. She revolutionized textile art and taught weaving.
Anni Albers.date_note: Faculty. Arrived with husband Josef from Germany.

Merce Cunningham.bio: Merce Cunningham was a dancer and choreographer who was guest faculty at Black Mountain College during multiple summer sessions. He collaborated closely with John Cage and created groundbreaking dance works.
Merce Cunningham.date_note: Guest Faculty - multiple summer sessions with Cage

R. Buckminster Fuller.bio: Buckminster Fuller was an architect, systems theorist, and inventor who was guest faculty at Black Mountain College. He attempted to build his first geodesic dome at the 1948 Summer Art Institute.

periods.note: Summer Art Institute, first dome attempt (collapsed)

Willem de Kooning.bio: Willem de Kooning was an abstract expressionist painter who was guest faculty at the 1948 Summer Art Institute at Black Mountain College.
Willem de Kooning.date_note: Guest Faculty - Summer Art Institute 1948 only
